And he suggests that the Caravan has not actually been that good for Tijuana itself.

utterances.speaker: GENARO LOPEZ MORENO, TIJUANA DELEGATE
utterances.utterance: They're still here. Problems are still going on. There's been like 280 arrests. Before, it was solely for drug possession and being drunk in the streets. Now, it's for breaking and entering into homes. People have even made citizen's arrest of (ph) them. And things aren't very nice here and the neighborhoods is tired of them, the merchants and the schools.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, what exactly is the matter with these people in Mexico? Why don't they like this Caravan? Ethan Bearman is a California radio host and he joins us tonight. Ethan, thanks a lot for coming on. So, I guess--

utterances.speaker: ETHAN BEARMAN, LIBERAL RADIO SHOW HOST
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --the reason we keep going back to this topic, and let me just stipulate, as I have before with you, that I - I like immigration. I like immigrants. I give every person in the Caravan the benefit of the doubt. I think most really do want to come here for a better life. What infuriates me is that nobody gives the residents of any country into which immigrants for (ph) the benefit of the doubt. All of them are dismissed immediately as bigots if they don't like it. What's so striking is that nobody in the Left is saying anything about the reaction of Mexican citizens in Tijuana to this Caravan, who are sounding like Donald Trump, all of a sudden. Why are people ignoring this?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: I don't know that they are ignoring it because we definitely recognize the plight of human beings that who have crossed from one of the poorest countries in the world that had 36 years of Civil War and is now the conduit of the cartels for exporting drugs to the United States. And that's what we're talking about with these people who are camped out there. You know, there - there are issues, obviously. Anytime you take a couple of thousand people and stick them in a stadium and tell them to just wait there with an unknown amount of time before they're going to be processed for asylum, you would have trouble with an unknown amount of time that you're stuck in a place as well, while you're trying to figure out how to bring your family to a country for a new life.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I - I believe that. And I probably wouldn't engage in any home invasions during that time. But, you know, who knows? Maybe it's a situational response. But here's what I'm, so again I was (ph), struck by, is everybody I talked to says we have deep sympathy for the plight of these migrants. And - and I said at the outset, and I mean it, I have sympathy too. I've never heard anybody in the Left say, you know, we have deep sympathy for like normal people who just want to pay their taxes and send their kids to school, and their lives are being overturned by this. There's an effect on the people who live there when new people come. And nobody cares about them at all. Even in Tijuana, nobody cares about them. Why is that?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: Well I think people do care about them. But here's the issue. We have a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Really? Who were (ph) their champions?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --we have two-fold problem. One, we - we - we - wait, champ - we have - we have a problem of governments failing but - both Mexican and U.S. governments failing to deal with this human refugee crisis. And then the people are stuck with that problem in the local community, especially, in places like Tijuana. And on top of it all, yes, we always have a problem with the other. There are deep-seated issues of implicit bias--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well but wait a second - wait a second--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --of people of (ph) a different economic status--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --OK, see, I know (ph) what you're - what you're saying is the people of Tijuana are bigots. And - and before we reach that conclusion, I think it's fair to look at the facts. So, there is at least one school in Tijuana that's been closed for three weeks because they can't open. People want to send their kids to school in Tijuana, in any place. There's trash all over the streets. It's super expensive. And there's been a crime spree. So, all I want from you and from everyone on the Left is an acknowledgement that there are real concerns that are not rooted in bigotry but that are rational and it's fair to be upset about this. But no one will give the benefit of the doubt to normal people, ever. Why?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: Well there's - there's definitely a right to be concerned about trash and - and the inability to send your kids to school and the environment and everything else.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: The crime?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: But again--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Is it OK being (ph)--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --blaming you got to figure out who--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --upset about crime?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --yes, of course, you can be upset. You should be upset about crime.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: And that is a problem. But you have to look at what the causes are and who's responsible for what is actually happening. You're taking people who have a - a - a problem with getting food. 67 percent of people from Guatemala have an inability to have regular access to food. They have extreme poverty. They're still dealing with the aftermath of a 36-year Civil War. They're still dealing with the aftermath of the United Fruit Company--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's a--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --that the United States sent down there and created the idea of--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --oh, oh, spare me the United Fruit Company. I mean, look, it was- -

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --a Banana Republic. We - we have all of these--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --it was a tough comp - country before--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --yes, we did that. And that's the term Banana Republic--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --the United Fruits were planting (ph) bananas there.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. But - OK, but again, I see all these religious figures, very self-righteous religious figures show up and say, "We're on the side of the migrants." Why do I never see anybody show up and say, we're on the side of just the normal people of Tijuana who aren't rich and have prosaic concerns like the rest of us? Why does no one if - on the Left ever go up and say, we're going to stand up for you?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm not sure I have a good answer for you there because the government and the way the system is set up--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --is for the citizens that are there in places like Tijuana or here in the United States. And we're talking about a refugee crisis that's happening, an asylum crisis--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --the earth (ph) of human beings and children. We just had the seven-year-old who died crossing over--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes, it's - it's terrible. It's terrible--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --in New Mexico because it's a desert (ph)--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --but I mean what about people in (ph)--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: So, we have a responsibility.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I guess. But we also have a responsibility to the people who already live in Tijuana and already live in this country, and they feel like no one cares about them, and that's why they elected Donald Trump, so like someone should care about them or else they're going to get madder, don't you think?

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: Well, of course, I do care about my fellow citizens.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: OK. Good.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: I - I - I clearly do. But the issue is again--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --you can't just kick people to the curb because you don't like them because they're refugees, and we view people of different socio and economic status with - with a bias, implicit bias. Go take the Harvard--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --one of their tests from Project Implicit. It's - it's a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Couldn't get into Harvard. But I - I see--

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: --it's a great way to understand how - how you feel.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --what you're saying. Ethan, thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: BEARMAN
utterances.utterance: No, online, Tucker. Online, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: What is it like to be inside a radical cell? We're going to speak, for the first time, a very interesting story, to a man who spent years as an anarchist in this country, very much like Antifa. What was that like? Well like a cult, actually. He'll explain it to us after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well the violent Left is a growing force in American politics and life from here in Washington to Portland, Oregon, to the Bay Area. And yet, even now, movements like Antifa remain mostly mysterious to news consumers. You, most of the time, just see them when they riot, couple 30-second clips, and that's about it. What is it like inside these groups? And what motivates their members? Conor Barnes spent years as part of an anarchist community. He later left the movement, and has published a pretty remarkable essay about his experiences in Quillette, which is excellent, by the way. Conor Barnes joins us tonight. Conor, thanks a lot for coming on. I - I was really struck by--

utterances.speaker: CONOR BARNES, FORMER ANARCHIST
utterances.utterance: Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --your piece. I don't think I've ever read an account - I know I've never read an account of what it's like to be at - at the center of something like this. By the way, I - I've no idea what your politics are now. I'm not even going to ask you. But I was interested that you described this as like a religious community almost.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes, there is a - a really strong faith-based component. You become absolutely sure that you're right and nothing's going to sway you from it. You've - you've set your course. You figured it out.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, it didn't seem, from your description, like there were a lot of other inputs coming into the cell. It seemed almost totally self- referential. You talk only to people--

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --you're in it with. What are the things that you convinced yourself of, or were convinced of when you were in this cell?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: Yes. Oh, just, gosh, everything. You were able to find what was wrong with everything from school to government to police to any interaction people had, you can find what's wrong with it. It's a - it's not a very happy way to live.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: What was your view of violence?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: So, violence - there's a - there's a shifty way people talk about it. Direct action and diversity of tactics, which is a subtle way of saying if somebody wants to be violent, we're going to turn our head and be OK with it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, it's not a non-violent movement?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Huh?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: It's a--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: How did you - how did you get into it?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: I was a pretty unhappy teenager. And I'm told that happens a lot to teenagers. And I went looking for an explanation. And I ended up just reading a lot of radical literature, and found more and more radical literature, until I found things that explained that happiness wasn't something you had much control over. Capitalism was keeping you down.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. What - what spurred you to leave it?

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: Yes. There were - I'd say there were two components. There was - there are nasty people in the scene, and I got mixed up with somebody and that kind of shook me out of my headspace and forced me to reconsider things. And I just started reading wider and wider literature and, you know, I encountered gradual things that made me go, oh, that totally changes, you know, that - that can't be true. You know, you - you get shocked out of the cult bit by bit.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Huh? Huh, interesting. Conor Barnes, I - I just want to say again to our audience, if you haven't read this piece, it's on Quillette. It's just so interesting. I've never seen anything like it. I really appreciate your--

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: Not so much (ph).

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --coming on tonight. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BARNES
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Colleges are banning comedians from telling offensive jokes when they perform. Is that the same as banning comedy entirely? Pretty much. We'll talk to a censored comedian after the break.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well free speech has been ebbing away on college campuses, of course, for many years. Now, colleges seem increasingly unable to take a joke, literally. Konstantin Kisin is a comedian. He's the host of the YouTube show, TRIGGERnometry. He was recently invited to perform at a college in London. But the group that invited him asked that he sign a contract promising not to engage in any way in, "Racism, sexism, classism, ageism, ableism, homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, xenophobia, Islamophobia, anti-religion, or anti-atheism," that's a long list. What was he supposed to joke about? Well, we've asked him to come on tonight to tell us. Mr. Kisin, thank you very much for coming on. First, is that real?

utterances.speaker: KONSTANTIN KISIN, CREATOR AND CO-HOST OF TRIGGERNOMETRY
utterances.utterance: Thank - thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Is that - did you make up that list as just (ph) a comedy bit?

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: No, it's not. It's been very good for my comedy. But, actually, if - if you go further into the contract, they also demanded that all jokes must be respectful and kind, which I think really takes the biscuit. And, as you know, I was born in the Soviet Union. And this really - getting this contract made me feel right at home.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's - it's a - it's a - it's a little ham-handed, I would say. But what is it - I mean you're a working comedian. That's why - why I'm so grateful you're on. What is your life like now?

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: Well it is getting very sensitive. And I think this is obviously an outline. No one would suggest that every university and college is like this.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: But I think the reason that I made a stand on this issue is I don't want it to get worse. I don't want this to--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: --continue.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, but it's so striking that this is being applied to comedians, these standards. They're being applied to all of us. We're all terrified. All of us live in fear. And freedom, really, is evaporating. But comedians used to be the one group that, by definition, was allowed to be transgressive because that's the whole point of comedy, saying the thing everyone else is afraid to say. Is it ominous, do you think, that comedians aren't even allowed to practice comedy?

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: I think so - I think so. We're - we're the canary in the coal mine. And I think this is why it's gone viral. I think it's nothing to do with comedy, this story, actually. The reason that people all around the world--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: --are tuning in and - and watching the video we recorded of - of this is because it's not about comedy. It's about ordinary people up and down the country in here in Britain and in America--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: --feeling like they can't say what they think. I've had so many messages from people messaging me, all kinds of people. Sometimes women going, you know what, I don't agree with radical feminism. And if I say that in the workplace tomorrow, I won't have a job anymore. So, what it's coming to is the fact that everybody feels like we're - we're all kind of under arrest. We are all - all--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: --everything we say can and will be used against us in a court of public opinion.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: And they're coming for the comedians first because we're - we're the ones that, as you say, are allowed to transgress. But everybody else feels it. And that's why the story's got the resonance that it has.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: It's not - this is not sustainable, this moment. Thank Heaven. Konstantin, thank you very much. God bless you for what you're doing. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: KISIN
utterances.utterance: Thanks for having me, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well a--

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.utterance: CAMPUS CRAZINESS.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --a free speech non-profit has sued the University of Texas saying the school has suppressed speech. Like many colleges, Texas has a special bias response team armed or unarmed, I'm not sure. But their purpose is to investigate alleged bias incidents at the school. More than a 100 such investigations have occurred in just the past year and a half. Nicki Neily is the President of Speech First that filed the lawsuit, and she joins us tonight. Nicki, thank you very much for coming on. What does your suit allege?

utterances.speaker: NICOLE NEILY, SPEECH FIRST PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: Sure. So, we allege that the University of Texas has four unconstitutional policies on the books. They have a verbal harassment policy, a campus climate response team, a bias response team, as you said, an acceptable use policy, which governs all internet and digital use on the - on the - on the campus, and then their residence hall manual. And all of those policies violate students' First and 14th Amendment rights because students are terrified to express their opinions. They don't know what they can be in trouble for. These policies are written so broad with such bizarre vague terms that students out of an - out of an abundance of caution just self-censor because they're terrified.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: So, this is like downtown Kandahar circa 2000, where the religious police come around in squads to check--

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: Right. Well it's - it's very much--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --to make sure that you're morally appropriate.

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: --yes, these terms are very vague. It's definitely in the eye of beholder. So, you know, what is offensive to me might not be offensive to you. But there are terms like rude, uncivil, insulting, derogatory. And so, I mean, you know--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Do they have enforcement power? Are there penalties for those who- -

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: There are enforcement penalties, yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: So, for the acceptable use policy, if you were to send a rude or uncivil email, you could be subject to a suspension and you might even be referred to the police for criminal prosecution, so.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Is there any, buried in the regulations, any hard definition of what rude is?

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: No, there's not. And there - therein lies the trouble. The devil's in the details because you have a bunch of unelected campus administrators and bureaucrats who are going to be the ones who are defining that. The verbal harassment policy actually says language that is not necessary to communicating political, philosophical, religious ideas, who's defining what's necessary? I mean is it going to be me as somebody who believes in the Constitution saying what's necessary or is it going to be someone who works for - for the Diversity and Inclusion Bureaucracy determining what's necessary?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I don't understand how a state school can ignore the Bill of Rights.

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: There you go. That's why we sued them.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't know what's going to happen. But I know I'm rooting for you. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: NEILY
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Good to see you. Well time now for The Friend Zone.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.utterance: THE FRIEND ZONE.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Friend Zone. We bring on one of our friends here at Fox on to the show. Dion Baia is one of our best friends here at Fox. He's one of the people who helps this place run. He's worked here for years as a Studio Tech. He appears on Your World with Neil Cavuto. And he has just written a novel, which I have read. It's called Blood in the Streets. Dion joins us now. So impressive that you went - by the way, the obvious question, when did you write this?

utterances.speaker: DION BAIA, ACTOR, BLOOD IN THE STREETS AUTHOR
utterances.utterance: Well, geez, I wrote this back, it started as a screenplay, so I wrote this years ago, 2003 to maybe 2006, and then I ended up turning it into a novel in 2012. And that was around the time you read it and, you know, you were so great to - to look it over and all that. And then it just took a couple years of refining it before I was able to, you know, get it out there to market, so to speak.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Why did you write a screenplay and then a novel?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I wanted to make it a movie. It was - it's - it's a - the - the book and - and its context now is very cinematic in my - I went to film school. My original idea was to make a movie and write myself in as like, say, Quentin Tarantino would do. So, I wrote the screenplay. And then, I just couldn't get anybody to look at it for a couple years. So, I didn't want to give up. So, I had the idea well maybe it'll be easier turning it into a novel and getting it published that way. So, in 2012, I turned it into a novel, and then it took a couple years and I finally got it out that way as this brain-spanking new novel, Blood in the Streets.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Amazing. Set where?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: In New Haven, Connecticut, where I was born and raised in the 1970s. So, it's a - it's kind of an homage to like, you know, the 70s gritty cop films, and it's a fiction but it is in a historical context set within New Haven in the 1970s.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Interesting. This is one of those books that, I think, really has only been read inside Fox News. I keep getting texts and emails about "Have you read this book? It's great."

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes, well thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: What's the reaction - what - have people outside the channel read it and what's the reaction, Baia?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: People close to me have and they've been messaging me that they like it. And I think they're just, you know, maybe they're just being nice. It's just so weird because I've been with the material so long in my head that it's now surreal that I never envisioned it now getting out there and that people are going to actually have a reaction to it and come up to me and ask me, you know, questioning me about it. So, it's just kind of - it's almost I'm taken aback by that, you know, that people are actually interested in - in talking to me about it. And I'm like "Wow, I never saw this day coming." So, it's surreal.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Better than the alternative.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: I've written ignored books before so (ph)--

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Super quick, are you writing a sequel?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, there is a sequel, which will be a prequel, yes, which--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: A sequel which will be a prequel?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes, a prequel to this. So--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. I'm - I'm too dyslexic to understand what that means but it sounds excellent and I'll be--

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --reading that one too.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Dion, it's great to see you.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Tucker, thank you so very much.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Congratulations, man.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Good to see you too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: You're a published Author of a novel, which is--

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: --not easy.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes, thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.utterance: Well this is a Fox News Alert, and certainly surprising. A Federal Judge in Texas has just struck down Obamacare, true story. Judge Reed O'Connor says the individual mandate, the part of the law that requires you to participate, is unconstitutional, and because it cannot be separated from the let - rest of the law, which it cannot be, the entire law is invalid. Now, the individual mandate, you'll remember, was previously upheld by the Supreme Court. But on the grounds that it was a tax, the fine for not following the mandate was eliminated last year. So, O'Connor says this makes that ruling invalid (ph) because it's no longer a tax. The ruling is certain to be appealed - appealed, obviously. Obamacare, by the way, was passed on March 21st, 2010. It was signed three days later. Wow! Didn't see that coming. We'll continue to follow it, obviously. That's it for tonight and for the week. Man, it went fast like all good things. We'll be back Monday at 8:00, the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness, and groupthink. DVR it if you can figure out how to do that. Tell us if you can. Mr. Chaffetz, in for Sean, right now. Have a great weekend. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 ASC Services II Media, LLC.
